utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We want China to cease its illegal cyber activities and honor its commitment to the international community.
The Justice Department has vowed to push back against China's actions.
One way it will do that, Rosenstein says, is by bringing more cases against individuals stealing on China's behalf.
Ryan Lucas, NPR News, Washington.
The Polish government is in a standoff with the European Union over human rights.
EU officials are investigating whether new laws in Poland weaken judicial independence.
The new government in Poland is outraged, accusing the EU of meddling.
Among the many stuck in the middle, women seeking to have babies.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson reports from Warsaw.
Many judicial experts say it's become nearly impossible to protect civil liberties in Poland since the Law and Justice Party took control there last fall.
The party, which won a solid parliamentary majority in national elections, has moved quickly to adopt laws that critics say weaken the power of the country's constitutional court.
But Malgorzata Gosiewska, a senior MP of the ruling Law and Justice Party, says they were actually trying to protect the court from political interference.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Foreign language spoken).
She accuses the constitutional court of siding with the Civic Platform party, which ran the previous Polish government.
The new Parliament sought replacements for nominees selected by the rival party to fill five vacancies on the 15-seat court.
Critics say the court's been paralyzed by a new mandate that at least 13 judges must be involved in every constitutional case.
With only 10 members on the court at the moment, it can't rule on anything.
Last Tuesday, the embattled head of the Constitutional Tribunal, Andrzej Rzeplinski, tried to compromise.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Foreign language spoken).
Looking pale and tired, he agreed to throw out two of previous nominees for his court, which means the new government would fill those two vacancies.
Rzeplinski told NPR the political crisis is impeding Polish justice.
Without those judges, we cannot work normally because there's no final decision about who can be a member of the court.
Critics of the new law say they threaten a quarter-century of democracy in Poland.
Adam Bodnar is the country's official ombudsman charged with protecting civil liberties.
I think this situation of the constitutional court is dreadful for human rights.
He says those affected include Polish women undergoing in vitro fertilization.
They are now subject to a new law requiring them to be married or have a partner in order to get pregnant by artificial means.
The problem is that there is a number of women who started procedure before this law was adopted.
They have frozen their embryos, and they would like to continue.

Bodnar says he would normally have gone to court to seek an exemption for the women, but with the courts stalled, the ombudsman says he has no idea how long it will take for these women to get legal relief.
Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson, NPR News, Warsaw.
From NPR News, this is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Tony Cox, in for Farai Chideya.
He's been in office just three months, but Florida's Republican Governor Charlie Crist is already shaking things up in the Sunshine State.
His latest move: restoring civil rights to ex-felons convicted of - in his words - less severe crimes.
The state's criminal database contains 628,000 convicted felons.
Currently, most Florida felons must wait five years after their release just to be able to petition for their civil rights.
But under a new clemency rule, state officials estimate that a half million offenders would qualify to serve on a jury, run for office and vote.
So what could this move mean for felons' rights nationwide, and how will it affect Florida's team-making status in the 2008 presidential election?
For answers, I'm joined now by Democratic political strategist Donna Brazile.
She was campaign manager for Al Gore's 2000 presidential run.
We are also joined by Paul Butler, professor of law at George Washington University and a former federal prosecutor.
Welcome to the both of you.
Thank you.
Donna, let me begin with you, before we get into the nuts and bolts of this.
How surprised are you that this comes at the behest of a Republican governor and in Florida, the new millennium centerpiece of presidential battlegrounds?
Well, first of all, Governor Crist said a couple of months ago, right before the election, that he intended to make some changes in the election law.
First, he announced that Florida would commit resources to ensure that the machines of democracy actually work - the voting machines.

And then, he went forward with lobbying members of the board that basically review these cases and was able to get the Agriculture Commission and Mr. Bronson and also one of the chief financial officer, who happens to be a Democrat, to embrace this proposal.
This is good news.
Okay.
Well, thank you, Sam.
Sam Eaton of Public Radio's daily business show MARKETPLACE.
It's produced by American Public Media.
That was - when I was writing the pilot, that was a scene that I sketched back then.
I was like, God, I want to see this, that whole storyline, especially 'cause I'm new to LA.
And we're the working class, right?
We are the nannies and the - we're judges and doctors, too.
But for a section of LA we are cleaning up after people.

And I really wanted to not just tell that story but also compare Lyn, who is such a - like, a social climber - for her to measure herself against that and be like, oh, they see us, and they will eventually see us as the same thing.
The way she was being exoticized - you know, they were talking about her Frida eyebrows and stuff like that - and it was like, eventually I will clean up your vomit, too.
Did you know going into the show how much Spanglish you wanted to use?
Well, I've written, like, 16 plays, and most of them are Spanglish.
So sometimes it's Espangles (ph), which is a Spanish base with English sprinkled on top.
And then backwards, you know, Spanglish - English base, Spanish sprinkle on top.
I know it was important to you in ""Vida"" not to have subtitles.
Yeah, absolutely, 'cause you don't go to Boyle Heights and get subtitles.
(Laughter).
I didn't want - realism is really important, you know, that it be naturalistic.
And it needs to sound like we sound.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""VIDA"")
UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR #4: (As character) Yo know.
Yo se que my days are numbered.
So I touch every leaf, every petal, and I grab it punos de tierra.
And it sounds like we sound without any translation.
You will miss stuff, though.
Like, you really won't...
Right, but was there ever a moment that an executive said, good effort, but we need you to do subtitles now?
Never.
No one said that to you?
Never.
That's an incredible respect for your artistic vision.
This is what I'm telling you.
And not what we hear about in Hollywood very often.
The first year was kind of like - I couldn't have, you know, fantasized about it better.
The second year, now I have to, like, worry about, like, you know, people do have to watch this.
So we have to think about ratings and stuff like that.
So are you now making artistic editorial choices to appeal to the audience that you're trying to attract?
No, but now I'm more anxious about it (laughter).
OK.
OK.
